snippet: Egypt has been largely insulated from the Islamist violence in the region, but it is now facing increasing terrorism as Egyptians return from jihad abroad to fight the country’s military-backed government.
abstract: Egypt, long insulated from Islamist violence in the region, faces increasing terrorism as Egyptians return from jihad abroad to fight country's military-backed government; ouster of Mohamed Morsi and ensuing sectarian clashes confirmed predictions among jihadi leaders that power could never be won through democracy, prompting several international terrorist groups to begin calling for Muslims to take up arms against government.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick reported from Cairo, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Mayy El Sheikh and Kareem Fahim contributed reporting from Cairo, and Mark Mazzetti from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Egypt has been largely insulated from the Islamist violence in the region, but it is now facing increasing terrorism as Egyptians return from jihad abroad to fight the country’s military-backed government.

headline.main: Jihadist Return Is Said to Drive Attacks in Egypt
headline.print_headline: Jihadist Return Is Said to Drive Attacks in Egypt

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
